    - [ ] Linux Mint 18.x
    - [ ] etc (PLEASE, WRITE DOWN YOUR OS)

5. Write down software version and firmware version

    - Software version: ROS2 latest
    - Firmware version: [x.x.x]
 
6. Write down the commands you used in order

    - Followed the ROS2 instructions here:
http://emanual.robotis.com/docs/en/platform/turtlebot3/ros2/#ros2
 
7. Copy and Paste your error message on terminal

    - No errors
  
8. Please, describe detailedly what difficulty you are in 

    - We have seen that the robot odom value is approximately 0.5x of the actual distance the robot travels when operating with teleop keyboard.

We measured this 3 times with different distances and velocities, and it appears that the robot:
1. Publishes values of distance that is 0.5x
2. Publishes values of velocity that is 0.5x. 

We tried to isolate where this is occuring in the code but we haven't so far. We DON'T see this problem in simulation, so maybe that is a clue that it is something in the firmware, but we don't know.

Please test with ROS2 on a robot and verify odom values are correct, or see if you can find the bug. We'd really like to do a demo with TB3 but this is causing SLAM and Navigation to be very confused.

    Hi,

i am working on a project where I want to replace the _Raspberry Pi 3_ of my _Turtlebot3 Waffle Pi_ with an Intel Nuc. But the Nuc wasn't delivered yet, so I am trying to use my Desktop PC as a replacement for the Pi.
The Desktop PC is running Windows 10 with Ubuntu 16.04 in an Oracle VM Virtual Box. 
I connectet the OpenCR via the USB cable to an USB-Port of the PC and gave the Virtual Box access to this USB-Port.
That is already enough to power up the OpenCR.
Than I went ahead and followed the instructions in the e-Manual. I installed everytghing that was ment for the Remote-PC and the TurtleBot (Pi), on my Desktop PC. I did not went through the SSH Setup, as my PC already is the TurtleBot-SBC.

So I went ahead and connected one Dynamixel to the OpenCR to see if it starts spinning when I run the following Teleoperaation - Keyboard commands.

[1]Terminal
$ roscore


[2]Terminal
$ roslaunch turtlebot3_bringup turtlebot3_robot.launch


[3]Terminal
$ export TURTLEBOT3_MODEL=waffle_pi
$ roslaunch turtlebot3_teleop turtlebot3_teleop_key.launch


Everything was running without errors and I was able to see changing Orientation-Values in the Topic-Monitor while turning the OpenCR on the table.
But the Dynamixel didn't start spinning while pressing 'W' in the [3]Terminal. (the values changed up to _linear vel=0.26_)

Rosgraph:
![Rosgraph](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/45329802/55170635-2ed24100-5177-11e9-8fe0-4f1226286ba5.png)
(I deactivated the LiDAR-Node in the launch file)

So I though it is because I haven't connected anny power source beside the USB-Connection. so I tried connecting the SMPS 12V 5A to the OpenCR and afterwards the Battery.  But still the Dynamixel wasn't moving.

![IMG_2064](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/45329802/55173310-c2a60c00-517b-11e9-8778-e149ff3017eb.JPG)

Does someone has an idea whats wrong ?

Many thanks in advance!
Phil

title: How to change robot model while adding new component or replacing a existing one for turtlebot3 waffle?
body:
ISSUE TEMPLATE ver. 0.2.0

1. Which TurtleBot3 you have?

    - [ ] Burger
    - [X] Waffle
    - [ ] Waffle Pi

2. Which SBC(Single Board Computer) is working on TurtleBot3?

    - [ ] Raspberry Pi 3
    - [ ] Intel Joule 570x
    - [X] etc (Intel NUC)

3. Which OS you installed in SBC?

    - [ ] Ubuntu MATE 16.04 or later
    - [ ] Raspbian
    - [X] etc (Ubuntu 18.04)

4. Which OS you installed in Remote PC?

    - [ ] Ubuntu 16.04 LTS (Xenial Xerus)
    - [X] Ubuntu 18.04 LTS (Bionic Beaver)
    - [ ] Linux Mint 18.x
    - [ ] etc (PLEASE, WRITE DOWN YOUR OS)
  
8. Please, describe detailedly what difficulty you are in 

The 360 LDS within turtlebot3 works well, but we plan to practice the depth_to_laserscan with depth image of RGB-D camera in order to replace the Laser Scan from the inherent LDS, moreover, we doesn't plan to use the R200 yet. However, once we try to install the new RGB-D camera on tutlebot3 waffe, the robot model (a.k.a URDF) should be updated for waffe, maybe there are 2 ways to go ahead:
- Option 1: put the new RGB-D camera to be installed at the position of the current LDS, but we want to keep the LDS, so this option is not the preference.
- Option 2: remove the R200 camera and put the new RGB-D camera at its position

For option 2, can we keep the original model description in the [turtlebot3_waffle.urdf.xacro](https://github.com/ROBOTIS-GIT/turtlebot3/blob/master/turtlebot3_description/urdf/turtlebot3_waffle.urdf.xacro) for R200 and use it for the new RGB-D camera for its TF transformation?
As per my basic understanding, it should be incorrect with the same one, because the new RGB-D camera (e.g Realsene D435i) has different shape with the R200, their centroid shouldn't be at the same point. Could you please give some suggestion to enable right robot model description for the new camera on the current turtlebot3 waffe to allow the map with cartographer to be usable and accurate based on the correct transformation of laser scan from the camera depth ?
Basically, we think that we need to measure the shape of the new camera with some specific scale and make clear the internal link transformation of the camera, for example depth_link to camera_link... but to be frankly, not experienced with this, so please give some guidelines. thanks !

    - N/A
  
8. Please, describe detailedly what difficulty you are in 

    - I'm trying to run the ros2 navigation2 on turtlebot3 on my TB3 waffle. I've replaced the Joule board with a NUC, installed and built all the software now. 

I am following the directions here: http://emanual.robotis.com/docs/en/platform/turtlebot3/ros2/#ros2

When I go to run, the directions are for the burger:
```
$ ros2 launch turtlebot3_bringup burger.launch.py
```
This will launch using the burger urdf file. Since the waffle is physically different, odometry will be different and it won't navigate correctly. 

So I'm requesting that the waffle urdf files be ported to ros2 and possibly that the launch file be changed to launch with either one. 

Please let me know if you can help and support this.

If not, if you could tell me of a good work-around, I can proceed that way also.

title: turtlebot3 navigation costmap2DROS transform timeout and Could not get robot pose
body:
ISSUE TEMPLATE ver. 0.2.0

Set-up
- TurtleBot3: Waffle Pi
- SBC: Raspberry Pi 3
- OS installed in SBC: Raspbian
- OS installed on remote PC: Ubuntu 16.04 LTS
- SW version: v1.12.13
- Firmware version: v1.2.3
- Commands:
    [remote PC] _roscore_
    [turtlebot] _roslaunch turtlebot3_bringup turtlebot3_robot.launch_
    [remote PC] _roslaunch turtlebot3_slam turtlebot3_slam.launch slam_methods:=gmapping_
    [remote PC] _rosrun map_server map_saver -f map_
    [remote PC] kill slam
    [turtlebot] kill bringup
    [turtlebot] _roslaunch turtlebot3_bringup turtlebot3_robot.launch_
    [turtlebot] _roslaunch turtlebot3_navigation turtlebot_turtlebot3_navigation.launch map=$HOME/map.yaml_
 
- Problem:
I am trying to follow the navigation portion of the e-manual and have been running into a couple problems. After running the last command, I get the error shown below. The second error, "**could not get robot pose, cancelling reconfiguration**", comes and goes. I typically use the RC100 to move the bot as using the teleop keyboard doesn't work when trying to move the robot but works in simulation. 

![navigation output](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14880579/52092214-d589cf00-2584-11e9-8a4e-c246132e0514.png)

I've tried redoing SLAM and trying navigation on the new map to see if maybe my map just isn't good but still get the same error. 

I've looked at other issues related to mine and have tried the proposed solutions (reseting OpenCR, restarting roscore and bringup, checking if turtlebot and the remote PC are on the same time using _ntpdate ntp.ubuntu.com_). None of these worked. 

I ran _roswtf_ to see what was wrong and noticed that the following nodes were not connected.

![roswtf output](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14880579/52093652-015b8380-258a-11e9-99e0-0cef331b8301.png)

I noticed in the related issues that there were mentions of topic frequencies (tf and odom) so I'm attaching tf_monitor output. When I ran _rostopic hz /tf_, the average frequencies ranged from 30Hz to 70Hz. It also says it's an unknown publisher?

![tf_monitor output](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14880579/52093989-3ddbaf00-258b-11e9-983c-947aac494b90.png)
 
I also get this issue sometimes when bringing up turtlebot3: [WARN] Failed to get param: timeout expired

I'm unsure of what is going wrong and would really appreciate any help in getting to the bottom of this! Thank you so much in advanced!

body:

4. Which OS you installed in Remote PC?

    - [x] Ubuntu 16.04 LTS (Xenial Xerus)
    - [ ] Ubuntu 18.04 LTS (Bionic Beaver)
    - [ ] Linux Mint 18.x
    - [ ] etc (PLEASE, WRITE DOWN YOUR OS)

5. Write down software version and firmware version

    - Software version: [x.x.x]
    - Firmware version: [x.x.x]
    - sorry, I couldn't figure out how to check the version, but I have updated them few minutes ago according to 
http://emanual.robotis.com/docs/en/platform/turtlebot3/faq/#fa
so they should be the latest version.
    - I am using Raspberry Pi Camera Module V2 camera module (Daylight - element14) for camera

6. Write down the commands you used in order

    - So I followed the instruction mentioned in the autonomous driving sector, "Tutorials: 4.4. Settings for Recognition" and "Tutorials: 5.1 Lane Detection" 
http://emanual.robotis.com/docs/en/platform/turtlebot3/autonomous_driving/#autonomous-driving

after completing all of the instructions on chapter 6,7,8,and ones up to this point on chapter 13 including camera calibration. (skipped chapters on SLAM and Simulation).
Just for ease of reading I have made a list below with an out of terminal instractions I followed intending to make the line follower work.

```
Tutorials: 4.4. Settings for Recognition

4.4.1 Remote PC Open new terminal, then enter
 $ roscore

4.4.2 TurtleBot SBC Open new terminal, then enter
 $ roslaunch turtlebot3_autorace_camera turtlebot3_autorace_camera_pi.launch

4.4.3 TurtleBot SBC Open new terminal, then enter
 $ export AUTO_IN_CALIB=action
 $ roslaunch turtlebot3_autorace_camera turtlebot3_autorace_intrinsic_camera_calibration.launch

4.4.4 Remote PC Open new terminal, then enter
 $ export AUTO_EX_CALIB=action
 $ roslaunch turtlebot3_autorace_camera turtlebot3_autorace_extrinsic_camera_calibration.launch



Tutorials: 5.1 Lane Detection

5.1.1 Remote PC Open new terminal, then enter
 $ export AUTO_DT_CALIB=calibration
 $ roslaunch turtlebot3_autorace_detect turtlebot3_autorace_detect_lane.launch

5.1.2 Remote PC Open new terminal, then enter
 $ rqt
clicking plugins -> visualization -> Image view on the top of the screen will make extra monnitor for camera view. Make 3 extra monitor in the rqt plate by following it. Then, choose /detect/image_yellow_lane_marker/compressed, /detect/image_lane/compressed and /detect/image_white_lane_marker/compressed topics on each of extra monitors.

5.1.3 Remote PC Open new terminal, then enter
 $ rosrun rqt_reconfigure rqt_reconfigure
then, adjust the parameter value in /camera/image_projection and /camera/image_compensation_projection that carries out visual modifications on the image. The parameter image_projection will change the shape of the red rectangle of /camera/image_extrinsic_calib/compressed image. Intrinsic camera calibration will transform the image surrounded by the red rectangle, and will show the image that looks from over the lane. After that, overwrite value on to the lane.yaml file in turtlebot3_autorace_detect/param/lane/. This will make the camera set its parameters as you set here from next launching.

5.1.4 Remote PC After overwriting the calibration file, close rqt_rconfigure and turtlebot3_autorace_detect_lane, then enter
 $ export AUTO_DT_CALIB=action
 $ roslaunch turtlebot3_autorace_detect turtlebot3_autorace_detect_lane.launch

5.1.5 Remote PC
 $ roslaunch turtlebot3_autorace_control turtlebot3_autorace_control_lane.launch

5.1.6 TurtleBot SBC
 $ roslaunch turtlebot3_bringup turtlebot3_robot.launch

After entering these commands, the robot will kick-off to run.


```

7. Copy and Paste your error message on terminal

There are several Errors I have recieved, but I am not sure which one is fundemental problem so I will make a list.

- 4.1.3
This might be a minor problem, but here some of the node could not be launched.
    ```
    TurtleBot SBC

    $ export AUTO_IN_CALIB=action
    $ roslaunch turtlebot3_autorace_camera turtlebot3_autorace_intrinsic_camera_calibration.launch
    ... logging to /home/pi/.ros/log/4fbf5770-1272-11e9-84aa-001c42da1064/roslaunch-raspberrypi-2601.log
    Checking log directory for disk usage. This may take awhile.
    Press Ctrl-C to interrupt
    Done checking log file disk usage. Usage is <1GB.

    started roslaunch server http://10.0.0.18:41425/

    SUMMARY
    ========

    PARAMETERS

      /
        republish (image_transport/republish)

    ROS_MASTER_URI=http://10.0.0.28:11311

    process[republish-1]: started with pid [2610]

    ROS path [1]=/home/pi/catkin_ws/src
    ROS path [2]=/opt/ros/kinetic/share
    ```

- 5.1.3

Here is where the main problem is. when I do
```
$ rqt
```
it works fine but when I try to Image view the /detect/image_yellow_lane_marker/compressed, /detect/image_lane/compressed and /detect/image_white_lane_marker/compressed, all three does not show any image but instead show a gradation from white to gray. I can see the normal image from camera on /camera/image without any problem.

- 5.1.6
Here the robot does not move.

8. Please, describe detailedly what difficulty you are in 

    - My ultimage goal is to make this algorithm work and make robot run following the lines, but I am encountering small errors here and there and I am not sure where to tackle. My guess for the main problem is the error happening on SBC when I try to 
    ```
        $ roslaunch turtlebot3_autorace_camera turtlebot3_autorace_intrinsic_camera_calibration.launch
    ```
    This problem has been happening throughout chapter 13, and I could only calbrate camera by running same command on remote PC when the manual told me to do so on SBC.

    Could someone help me figure out how this error on 4.1.3 is happening and hopefully get my line trace cord working?

    Regards.

title: Enable turtlebot3_teleop_key to work on Windows
body: Currently turtlebot3_teleop_key is using termios to scan the keyboard input but it is Unix only module. I am proposing to use **msvcrt.getch()** on Windows, so this script can work on both systems.

title: Question about TurtleBot3 navigation
body: I work with a robot(Turtlebot3 burger) and I can not find anywhere about which algorithm is used by default in navigation global planner. I know that local planner is dynamic window approach(dwa_local_planner). The only information about global planner I found was the algorithm Rapidly Exploring Random Trees (RRT), but I do not know if this is the default setting. I will add that I did not change anything in the robot settings, I use official packages. I am asking for clarification of the problem and information about the navigation algorithms used. I generally need information on what happens in the program when I set the "2D Nav Goal" in RVIZ during navigation.

title: Fixed missing semicolons after RCLCPP_INFO
body: Some RCLCPP_INFO lines were missing semicolons.

title: Navigation in Gazebo not working with realistic update rate of laser scanner
body:
Hi,

I try to run the Turtlebot3 navigation demo in Gazebo as described in the [e-manual](http://emanual.robotis.com/docs/en/platform/turtlebot3/simulation/#simulation).
However, with the normal configuration of the Turtlebot3 Bruger Gazebo model I always run into the following problem:
![screenshot from 2018-11-22 15-37-29](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12223752/48909085-96484f00-ee6c-11e8-96e6-6f2e47213954.png)
However, if I change from `<update_rate>5</update_rate>` to a higher value like 25 Hz this issue does not arise. Probably this didn't occur with the update rate at 1800 Hz as well which was changed in #258. As 5 Hz is the frequency of the real sensor it should run with this value. Do you run into this problem as well?

It should be reproducible by following the steps in the e-manual:
1. Launch simulation:  'export TURTLEBOT3_MODEL=burger' then  'roslaunch turtlebot3_gazebo turtlebot3_world.launch'
2. Launch navigation: 'export TURTLEBOT3_MODEL=burger' then 'roslaunch turtlebot3_navigation turtlebot3_navigation.launch map_file:=/home/some_dir/catkin_ws/src/turtlebot3/turtlebot3_navigation/maps/map.yaml' (If you installed from source specify the file location accordingly)

My setup:
ROS Melodic, Gazebo version 9.0.0 on Ubuntu 18.04
I installed this (meta)package from source.
The only changes I made were in fixing the map.yaml (like: #348) and removing the leading slashes from the frames specified in the [global](https://github.com/ROBOTIS-GIT/turtlebot3/blob/master/turtlebot3_navigation/param/global_costmap_params.yaml) and [local costmap](https://github.com/ROBOTIS-GIT/turtlebot3/blob/master/turtlebot3_navigation/param/local_costmap_params.yaml) parameter files. As the ROS navigation stack switched to tf2 we need to remove the leading slashes to comply with tf2.

Do you encounter this problem as well? Any help appreciated, thanks!

```
<launch>
  <arg name="multi_robot_name" default=""/>
  <arg name="set_lidar_frame_id" default="base_scan"/>

  <include file="$(find turtlebot3_bringup)/launch/turtlebot3_core.launch">

  </include>
  <include file="$(find turtlebot3_bringup)/launch/turtlebot3_lidar.launch">
    <arg name="set_frame_id" value="$(arg set_lidar_frame_id)"/>
  </include>

  <node pkg="turtlebot3_bringup" type="turtlebot3_diagnostics" name="turtlebot3_diagnostics" output="screen"/>
</launch>
```

which launches: **turtlebot3_core.launch**
```
<launch>
  <arg name="multi_robot_name" default=""/>

  <node pkg="rosserial_python" type="serial_node.py" name="turtlebot3_core" output="screen">
    <param name="port" value="/dev/ttyACM0"/>
    <param name="baud" value="115200"/>
    <param name="tf_prefix" value="$(arg multi_robot_name)"/>
  </node>
</launch>
```
The former is being run using this params:
`ROS_NAMESPACE=tb3_1 roslaunch turtlebot3_bringup turtlebot3_robot.launch multi_robot_name:="tb3_1" set_lidar_frame_id:="tb3_1/base_scan"`

but the TF tree doesn't successfully grab the namespace configuration for the `odom` and `base_footprint`: [TF Tree here](https://imgur.com/a/RG4MiWe)

I'm getting this warning on the console when launching (not sure if it has relation or not): [Here](https://imgur.com/a/uYud34B)

I've gone through the source code for both the `serial_node.py` and `SerialClient.py`, and effectively there's no room in the code to grab the namespace for the frames (`odom` & `base_footprint`), I've added the simple fix for the former source file:
`tf_prefix = rospy.get_param('~tf_prefix','')  #line 53`
`client = SerialClient(port_name, baud, tf_prefix=tf_prefix, fix_pyserial_for_test=fix_pyserial_for_test) #line 90`

but for the `SerialClient.py` the patching becomes a bit tricky (posted the same issue at the rosserial_python git but seems like it's not actively maintained, so hope over here I'd get some support)

```
def __init__(self, port=None, baud=57600, tf_prefix=None, timeout=5.0, fix_pyserial_for_test=False): #line 324
# fix for grabbing namespace configurations (line 336)
        if tf_prefix== None:
            # namespace was not initialized
            pass
        else:
            # setting the argument var to class var
            self.tf_prefix=tf_prefix
```
(this was the easy part)

after these come `setupPublisher(self, data):` & `setupSubscriber(self, data):`, and here becomes tricky, I've been spending the last couple of hours working the code, but the debugging gets a bit complex since we're working directly over the robot and the battery runs out very fast. So that's the reason I dare to ask for help from you guys.

(Read the two previous closed issues about this, however, it seems like the fix in the firmware wasn't yet added to the mainstream??)

Is it my guess that the problem can be fixed by changing this code correct? please advice otherwise.

Thanks

title: Added an additional argument move_forward_only to prohibit backward l…
body:
This PR is the resolution for #330 . 

If you set:
move_forward_only:=true

TB3 goes from the wheel base side only (no backward locomotion).

title: Add use_gui arg to turtlebot3_model.launch
body:
~This allows to use:~  
~$ export TURTLEBOT3_MODEL=${TB3_MODEL}
$ roslaunch turtlebot3_bringup turtlebot3_model.launch use_gui:=false~

Instead of:
```bash
$ export TURTLEBOT3_MODEL=${TB3_MODEL}
$ roslaunch turtlebot3_bringup turtlebot3_remote.launch
$ rosrun rviz rviz -d `rospack find turtlebot3_description`/rviz/model.rviz
```

An advantage is that the user does not need to write the backticks. This follows the concept of the `slam `and `navigation `launch files, which already includes the remote and rviz-config.

~The default of the new arg is set to "true" to make it compatible with the current launch file. Since I have not seen this launch file being used in the docs, one could also consider to set the default to "false".~


Also, I reused/included the `remote.launch` to replace the `description.launch` and `robot_state_publisher`.

title: teleoperating Turtlebot3 burger with LeapMotion
body:
In the user manual, you have the following instructions: 

```
LEAP Motion
[Remote PC] Connect LEAP motion to the remote PC via Bluetooth.

[Remote PC] Install packages for teleoperation using LEAP motion.

LEAP Setup
Download SDK
$ leapd
$ LeapCommandPanel
$ git clone git@github.com:warp1337/rosleapmotion.git
[Remote PC] Run teleoperation package for LEAP motion.

$ rosrun leap_motion sender.py
```
But I bet these steps only get Leap Motion work on the Remote PC. How about the communication?
Can you please show me more details on how to accomplish this task? Don't I need a package to build up the communication between Leap Motion and turtlebot3?

    - HERE
  
8. Please, describe detailedly what difficulty you are in 

    - We are in difficulty of TB3 navigation. TB3 goes backward frequently when it perform path planning. Also, it rotates infinitely around the goal.

We solved our issues with these parameter changes:

min_x_vel: 0
> prevent backward locomotion
https://github.com/ROBOTIS-GIT/turtlebot3/blob/master/turtlebot3_navigation/param/dwa_local_planner_params_waffle_pi.yaml#L5

min_rot_vel: 0.4 
> default value 0.9 is too fast. 0.4 is from TB2.
https://github.com/ROBOTIS-GIT/turtlebot3/blob/master/turtlebot3_navigation/param/dwa_local_planner_params_waffle_pi.yaml#L23

We are wondering how you fine tune these parameters set as the default. Any ideas?

8. Please, describe detailedly what difficulty you are in 

 I succeeded to do some 2d nav goal (especially when the free path is so wide and no obstacle), and the robot moved precisely to the goal pose.


Problem 1)
However, when the robot moved along narrow path like on this picture, the lidar seems like detect an obstacle ahead even it's a free narrow path, i want to move through this narrow alley but the robot will not move there because it think it's a obstacle. This is not always happening, but more frequently than normal (no false obstacle detected).

Rviz view (detect obstacle ahead)
![bug](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/36762228/46645617-eff00500-cbaf-11e8-8a55-b5d3e34f557c.png)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/36762228/46645972-b8825800-cbb1-11e8-9bf3-5d5eb76f0a4b.png)


Question for problem 1:

Why the turtlebot thinks it encounter obstacle when it's clearly free way ahead?
-Is it because the tolerance of costmap (even it's free way, if it is narrow it cannot be passed occasionaly)? -Is my Lidar not reliable anymore?



Problem 2)
I set my Lidar in 35 cm height, so the laser scan only detect at that height, sometimes i have short obstacle like 20 cm box in the real environment. Because of this, the robot sometimes make trajectory that collide with this short box.

Question for problem 2:  
1. Can I add  like ultrasonic sensor on 20 cm height as complementary distance sensor (this sensor only works for obstacle avoidance in navigation, to alter the trajectory avoiding this short obstacle that missed by laser scan)
2. If yes, is there any tutorial for this situation?


Thank you very much for paying attention to my problem

4. Which OS you installed in Remote PC?

    - [X] Ubuntu 16.04 LTS (Xenial Xerus)
    - [ ] Ubuntu 18.04 LTS (Bionic Beaver)
    - [ ] Linux Mint 18.x
    - [ ] etc (PLEASE, WRITE DOWN YOUR OS)

5. Write down software version and firmware version
    -> _ROS Kinetic_

My turtlebot setup was working last week but I cannot get any results from publishing to the /cmd_vel node and am thus stuck. I am trying to get the dynamixel motors working with the TB3 and I am running into some very cumbersome issues, as documented below. I've followed the instructions for troubleshooting that I was provided and while the OpenCR board seems to be working properly, I am not able to get the motors working. I have ensured the LiPO is fully charger (12.45 V) and I was able to follow instructions to upload arduino code and test the board (for example, by executing the BLINK example code). However, when I tried to run the turtlebot3_setup_motor code or the turtlebot3_core codes, I keep receiving an error message reading "cmd_read_board_name fail : 0xF020" and errors about not being able to open the location /dev/ttyACM0.

![image 3](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/32280929/46116299-47ee3b00-c1b0-11e8-8f84-9e3af37b0a8a.png)

The OpenCR board (STMicroelectronics STM32F407) is only detected after holding the boot and reset buttons (entering DFU mode) for a couple of seconds and then running a second lsusb command.

![image 2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/32280929/46116305-53416680-c1b0-11e8-8d80-ad005587e0e0.png)

![image 1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/32280929/46116313-5a687480-c1b0-11e8-867e-ebf07a1fd200.png)

***Additional:** 
I've also tried to burn the bootloader so that I could essentially "reset" the OpenCR board and then be able to reflash it with a new firmware (currently 1.2.3) but i cannot do so because the Arduino throws an error that it cannot burn the bootloader. Its an intriguing issue that I cannot seem to deal with, so please let me know if you can help at all.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/32280929/46116368-a1ef0080-c1b0-11e8-8a9b-ac334dbd6823.png)

The goal of the troubleshooting was that I would be able to manually/more directly determine if the motors are working before using 'turtlebot3_robot.launch' roslaunch file to launch the main TB3 functionalities. However, after attempting the troubleshooting steps described above, I am not even able to launch this 'turtlebot3_robot.launch' file because of the errors seen.

body:
ISSUE TEMPLATE ver. 0.2.0

1. Which TurtleBot3 you have?

    - [X] Waffle - my purchase from Robosavvy was a Waffle Pi kit with Realsense kit to upgrade the SBC and add the R200 depth camera.

    - [ ] Raspberry Pi 3
    - [ ] Intel Joule 570x
    - [X] Intel Atom based UP board (included in the Intel Realsense R200 developer kit provided by Robosavvy with the TurtleBot3) 

3. Which OS you installed in SBC?

    - [ ] Ubuntu MATE 16.04 or later
    - [ ] Raspbian
    - [X] See below - I am not sure - advice needed as the Robotis eManual only has instructions for the Intel Joule. 

4. Which OS you installed in Remote PC?

    - [X] Ubuntu 16.04 LTS (Xenial Xerus)
    - [ ] Ubuntu 18.04 LTS (Bionic Beaver)
    - [ ] Linux Mint 18.x
    - [ ] etc (PLEASE, WRITE DOWN YOUR OS)

5. Write down software version and firmware version

    See (8) below. Instructions for Up SBC install are needed - software  & firmware is not yet installed.

    - Software version: [x.x.x]
    - Firmware version: [x.x.x]
 
6. Write down the commands you used in order

    Instructions for Up SBC install needed - software  & firmware not yet installed.
 
7. Copy and Paste your error message on terminal

    Not applicable.
  
8. Please, describe detailedly what difficulty you are in 

There are no instructions in the Robotis eManual for the set up of the Up board that was supplied with the Realsense kit that I was sent with my order. This page for the set up of the single board computer from the manual - http://emanual.robotis.com/docs/en/platform/turtlebot3/sbc_setup/ only has instructions are for the Intel Joule 570X. The steps for the Intel Joule (http://emanual.robotis.com/docs/en/platform/turtlebot3/joule_setup/#joule-setup) refers to this link (https://software.intel.com/en-us/flashing-the-bios-on-joule) for a BIOS update in which the board is flashed by connection to a PC via the USB-C connection. 

The only thing that I could find online relating to both the Up and Turtlebot3 was this post - https://community.robotsource.org/t/convert-a-turtlebot3-waffle-pi-to-use-up-board-with-r200-camera/1397/4 - where one of the Robotis team, Leon_Ryuwoon_Jung seems to have said that they tried this combination back in 2016. 

Please can you point  me to an updated version of the eManual where they detail the Up board set up? Please also let me know which connectors (USB3 on-the-go and other) to use for both the BIOS upgrade (if needed) and Turtlebot3 build.

PS. I found the procedure for flashing the BIOS on the UP that I found on their Wiki web site (https://wiki.up-community.org/Bios_Update) seem to recommend that it is done without a connection straight off a USB drive. Is it relevant?

title: Bigger wheels for friends
body:
Hi! This may not be the right place to post this... But let me try. 
We are modifying our TB3 and we'd like to put bigger wheels on the modified "friend". We  want to have greater clearance.

Does Robotis sell wheels that would fit the four screw setup but that are around 4" in diameter? We know this will affect other things, but for now I am just wondering about the wheels.

title: turtlebot3_follower does not work, and always return with 'empty'
body:
Hello, we use Turtlebot3 with **Kinetic on Ubuntu 16.04**.

```
## Predict the position
[x for (x , y) in self.labels.iteritems() if y == self.clf2.predict(laser_data_set) ] 
print 'check_people return x:',x
print 'check_people return y:',y
```
```
[x for (x , y) in self.labels.iteritems() if y == self.clf.predict(data_test_set) ] 
print 'laser_scan return x:',x
return x
```

we have add some print to output the “x” and “y” from the function [check_people(self)](https://github.com/ROBOTIS-GIT/turtlebot3_applications/blob/kinetic-devel/turtlebot3_follower/scripts/follower.py#L39-L47) and [laser_scan(self)](https://github.com/ROBOTIS-GIT/turtlebot3_applications/blob/kinetic-devel/turtlebot3_follower/scripts/follower.py#L67), But all of them are "empty", as following list.

> check_people return x: empty
> check_people return y: 7
> laser_scan return x: empty
> check_people return x: empty
> check_people return y: 7
> laser_scan return x: empty

And we found a strange point, the value of [ret](https://github.com/ROBOTIS-GIT/turtlebot3_applications/blob/kinetic-devel/turtlebot3_follower/scripts/follower.py#L41-L47) in **check_people(self)** is always 1, it means the node always consider check_people successfully. Is it wrong?
  
Can you explain how to use the [clf](https://github.com/ROBOTIS-GIT/turtlebot3_applications/blob/kinetic-devel/turtlebot3_follower/scripts/clf) and [clf2](https://github.com/ROBOTIS-GIT/turtlebot3_applications/blob/kinetic-devel/turtlebot3_follower/scripts/clf2) to achieve [laser_scan(self)](https://github.com/ROBOTIS-GIT/turtlebot3_applications/blob/kinetic-devel/turtlebot3_follower/scripts/follower.py#L49) and [check_people(self)](https://github.com/ROBOTIS-GIT/turtlebot3_applications/blob/kinetic-devel/turtlebot3_follower/scripts/follower.py#L19) correctly? Or how to implement the forecasting process? Thanks for read first!

title: Configuring true slam with gmapping and navigation
body:
Turtlebot3 with Kinetic on Ubuntu 16.04

1. Reading the book and looking at the wiki, I see how to create and save a map using gmapping and in a separate step using that map for navitation.

2. I also know from @robotpilot that the included launch file for cartographer is supposed to show mapping and navigation happening at the same time. But I dont want to use cartographer because it's a special version and a special build which created other confusion in my catkin_ws directory.

3. Looking at the launch files, I am not clever enough to figure out how the cartographer launch file accomplishes this. 

Can you explain how to create a launch file which would create a map while teleopping and in the same run use the parts of the map that are done for navigation? I need to understand this in order to set up my own launch files etc. Thanks!

    - HERE
I followed the instructions in the Robotis Turtlebot3 manual here -  http://emanual.robotis.com/docs/en/platform/turtlebot3/pc_setup/

(A) Install Ubuntu on PC - ISSUE #1

Because the current version of Ubuntu is 18.0.4, I couldn't use the link in your user manual to install Ubuntu 16.0.4.  The download link in the Robotis manual on page (http://emanual.robotis.com/docs/en/platform/turtlebot3/pc_setup/) is https://www.ubuntu.com/download/alternative-downloads. The 16.0.4 link leads to this page http://cdimage.ubuntu.com/netboot/16.04/?_ga=2.105723779.1610410129.1535970811-665810113.1535820947 which has more links, not an ISO image as would be expected from the URL. The amd64 link which I used (as I was installing Ubuntu over a previous Windows 7) then led to this page - http://archive.ubuntu.com/ubuntu/dists/xenial-updates/main/installer-amd64/current/images/netboot/ - which just had directories and files, not and ISO image.

For the reason above, I used the following links instead:

a. Link to obtain the ISO image of Ubuntu 16.0.4 from http://releases.ubuntu.com/16.04/. The ISO image is at:

   http://releases.ubuntu.com/16.04/ubuntu-16.04.5-desktop-amd64.iso

b. Instructions to create a bootable USB:

https://tutorials.ubuntu.com/tutorial/tutorial-create-a-usb-stick-on-windows?_ga=2.157960632.304329474.1535820947-665810113.1535820947#3

(B) Install ROS

I then followed instructions 6.1.2 'Install ROS on remote PC' using the terminal commands below. This worked fine.

$ sudo apt-get update
$ sudo apt-get upgrade
$ wget https://raw.githubusercontent.com/ROBOTIS-GIT/robotis_tools/master/install_ros_kinetic.sh && chmod 755 ./install_ros_kinetic.sh && bash ./install_ros_kinetic.sh

(C) Install dependent ROS packages - ISSUE #2 

The command below installed most of the dependent packages - see state below - but it generated an installing ros-kinetic-map-server. This is the error upon which I an currently stuck:

$ sudo apt-get install ros-kinetic-joy ros-kinetic-teleop-twist-joy ros-kinetic-teleop-twist-keyboard ros-kinetic-laser-proc ros-kinetic-rgbd-launch ros-kinetic-depthimage-to-laserscan ros-kinetic-rosserial-arduino ros-kinetic-rosserial-python ros-kinetic-rosserial-server ros-kinetic-rosserial-client ros-kinetic-rosserial-msgs ros-kinetic-amcl ros-kinetic-map-server ros-kinetic-move-base ros-kinetic-urdf ros-kinetic-xacro ros-kinetic-compressed-image-transport ros-kinetic-rqt-image-view ros-kinetic-gmapping ros-kinetic-navigation ros-kinetic-interactive-markers

title: Lidar spins as soon as Ubuntu Mate boots up on TB3 Burger
body:
I am setting up a new TB3 and unlike the other ones we have, this one has a couple of oddities, maybe related:

1. As soon as Ubuntu Mate is running, the lidar spins
1. The OpenCR continues with its led's flashing in a sequence
1. During booting of Mate, the very first message is "failed to start load kernel modules"

I am still installing ROS itself but everything seems totally normal other than those three weird behaviors. Do you know what they mean?

title: Assembly instructions
body:
### Turtlebot3 Burger

On page 19 of the paper booklet, when connecting the two cables from the two dynamixels to the opener board, it's not indicated which one goes where. Which is weird because you ask me to specifically put unit number 1 on the left and number 2 on the right. 

Which cable goes where then?

title: What is cmd_vel_rc100?
body:
I am experimenting with slam and navigation and have seen some odd behavior, the bucking on going in reverse which I have asked about elsewhere.

In trying to track this down I was monitoring cmd_vel to make sure there was no one sending it twist 0's and indeed there were none.

But out of curiosity I monitored cmd_vel_rc100 and I do see a stream of zero twists going to that. That looks pretty suspicious but I don't know what it means.

title: Turtlebot3 Weight Distribution
body:
As mentioned in answers.ros.com, my TB3 exhibits a "bucking" or "stuttering" behavior when moving backwards. I am investigating whether somehow the TB3 is getting contradictory cmd_vel messages as we think might be the case.

I have a specific question for Robotis tough: Would balance or center of gravity affect this? Or would the condition of the caster ball? The caster ball does move freely. But I notice that the caster ball side is a little bit lower than the wheel side. Is that normal?

title: Possible error in book page 323
body:
This one is a little more involved. I have a burger, but as I was going to run topics out of a bag I assumed it was ok to pretend that I have a waffle.

I saved the downloaded bag in my ~ directory
I ran the tb3_remote.launch without problem

$ export TURTLEBOT3_MODEL=waffle
$ rosrun rviz rviz -d `rospack find turtlebot3_slam`/rviz/turtlebot3_slam.rviz

And then I got error:

$ roscd turtlebot3_slam/bag
$ rosbag play ./TB3_WAFFLE_SLAM.bag

[ INFO] [1534196625.075223331]: Opening /home/robot/TB3_WAFFLE_SLAM.bag
**[FATAL] [1534196625.075631789]: Error reading version line**

Is the bag I downloaded bad?

title: Possible error in book at page 323
body: The url for the waffle slam bag is incorrect.

title: Possible error in book on page 320
body:
If I understand correctly...

On page 320 it is stated that the turtlebot3_slam turtlebot3_slam.launch will not launch rviz, and that Rviz needs to be run in the next step. But looking at the launch file, it does run Rviz. Am I missing something?

title: Cheapest wireless joystick recommended?
body: I see many different "ps3 joysticks" on Amazon. Can you recommend one that will work easily and well?

title: Why include gazebo.xacro files into the urdf.xacro files
body:
Hi,
May I please ask why do I have to include relevant gazebo.xacro files into the urdf.xacro files in the beginning? Do Gazebo and Rviz use this same urdf.xacro file? Or we only include the gazebo.xacro files for the use of robot visualization in Gazebo? Thanks.
Below is just an example of including a relevant gazebo.xacro file into the urdf.xacro file
<xacro:include filename="$(find turtlebot3_description)/urdf/turtlebot3_waffle.gazebo.xacro"/>

body: I am running the Slam and Navigation examples in the tutorial. It shows making the map first and then navigating on the map. How do I do both at the same time, that is, navigate over the known part of the map while expanding the map elsewhere?

title: Maximum velocities and related questions
body:
I am writing a new custom teleop application. I am using a turtlebot3 burger. 

I have read here and there that you have to be careful about what motion commands you give the robot because you might harm it. So I have some questions:

1) How fast is it ok to send cmd_vel topics
2) Should I stop sending them when a specific max speed is reached? What is that speed?
3) How about changing velocities: If I sent cmd_vel: x = 0.22 may I send one for cmd_vel x = 0 right after or do I need to step down gradually? How gradually?

Can you give me some guidance?

title: Question on the config file for cartographer
body:
Hello,

I have been working with a Turtlebot 3 waffle PI and cartographer for some months and I saw you changed two parameters in the config file : *imu_sampling_ratio* and *odometry_sampling_ratio*, from 1 to 0.1.

I ran the offline node with 5 different bags and several values of the *odometry_sampling_ratio*, no value was better than the others, it looked like one random value just fit well with one bag. I also didn't find a more theoretical explanation, so do you have a particular reason for this modifcation ?

Thanks in advance.

title: Turtlebot behavior in the real world
body:
Tell me if this is the wrong place to post this question.

I am working with my Turtlebot3 Burger, in a 4 x 10m room that is carpeted. 

When driving forward the robot does ok, but sometimes it seems to stick and stutter.

When driving backwards, it's pretty terrible. It buckles and bounces and moves very roughly.

What might be causing this?

Do you not qualify the TB3 for riding on carpeted surfaces? 

Thanks!

title: Turtlebot 3 Slam
body:
I'm following along the TB3 tutorial wiki and experimenting with Slam. It is working ok. I am seeing the edge conditions and saw various odd warnings which are concerning:

```
$ ros_wtf
ERROR The following nodes should be connected but aren't:
 * /move_base->/move_base (/move_base/global_costmap/footprint)
 * /move_base->/move_base (/move_base/local_costmap/footprint)
```

Also from `roslaunch turtlebot3 navigation turtlebot3_navigation.launch map file:=... I got:

-- 4172.2622, global_pose stamp: 1532714171.7426, tolerance: 0.5000

title: Advice on obstacle detection
body:
ISSUE TEMPLATE ver. 0.2.0

1. Which TurtleBot3 you have?

    - [x] Burger
    - [ ] Waffle
    - [ ] Waffle Pi

2. Which SBC(Single Board Computer) is working on TurtleBot3?

    - [x] Raspberry Pi 3
    - [ ] Intel Joule 570x
    - [ ] etc (PLEASE, WRITE DOWN YOUR SBC HERE)

3. Which OS you installed in SBC?

    - [ ] Ubuntu MATE 16.04 or later
    - [x] Raspbian
    - [ ] etc (PLEASE, WRITE DOWN YOUR OS)

4. Which OS you installed in Remote PC?

    - [x] Ubuntu 16.04 LTS (Xenial Xerus)
    - [ ] Ubuntu 18.04 LTS (Bionic Beaver)
    - [ ] Linux Mint 18.x
    - [ ] etc (PLEASE, WRITE DOWN YOUR OS)

8. Please, describe detailedly what difficulty you are in 

    - Hello again ROBOTIS team, I don't have an issue but just a question about turtlebot 3 and hoping you could give me some guidance. I want to know if I can implement a PID control system on the robot speed aka dynamixels using the lidar to avoid collision with obstacles. The idea is the turtlebot would follow a line using the IR sensors I attached and while following the line it would use lidar sensor to detect anything in front of it and it would slow down or stop according to the distance in between. While doing this the object in front can move too but the turtlebot must move accordingly. 

Question: How can I use the Obstacle Detection [Here](http://emanual.robotis.com/docs/en/platform/turtlebot3/basic_examples/#obstacle-detection) to adjust the speed of the dynamixels rather than stopping immediately. I want to use Arduino IDE for this and vary the speed of dynamixels according to the distance detection made from lidar. I found in the machine learning section about this however there is no such information. I am looking forward to your help and would gladly answer questions to clear any confusion.

title: Installation instructions
body:
In the book you state that this will do a complete installation of kinetic, rod, and tb3 components:

```
$ wget https://raw.githubusercontent.com/ROBOTIS-GIT/robotis_tools/master/install_ros_kinetic.sh
$ chmod 755 ./install_ros_kinetic.sh
$ bash ./install_ros_kinetic.sh
```

Does that procedure take care of all the steps that are in the TUrtlebot3 Wiki at this url: http://emanual.robotis.com/docs/en/platform/turtlebot3/pc_setup/#pc-setup

Because a single comprehensive master install script would be really nice!

title: Replace a hard coded path with the default path of  `image` in map.yaml.
body:
When turtlebot3_navigation.launch is run, an error will occur with default `map_file` param.
The file path in map.yaml is odd.

title: Navigation tutorial: amcl problem ?
body:
Hi there !

1. Which TurtleBot3 you have?

    - [X] Burger
    - [ ] Waffle

    - [X] Xenial 16.04 + Kinetic, native on the TB3, inside a docker container (FROM osrf/ros:kinetic-desktop-full) on my Fedora 27 laptop

5. Write down software version and firmware version

    - Software version: [1.12.13 on both the TB3 and the docker container on my laptop]
    - Firmware version: [x.x.x]
 
6. Write down the commands you used in order

    - following the robotis tutorials:

      [laptop]
      roscore

      [tb3]
      roslaunch turtlebot3_bringup turtlebot3_robot.launch

      [laptop]
      roslaunch turtlebot3_slam turtlebot3_slam.launch slam_methods:=gmapping

      I move the robot using the android app and when the map is complete I run:

      rosrun map_server map_saver -f ~/map
    
      Then I kill stop the former gmapping task, move the robot by hand to a reference place in the room, and launch the navigation task:

      roslaunch turtlebot3_navigation turtlebot3_navigation.launch map_file:=/home/ros/map.yaml


 
7. Copy and Paste your error message on terminal

    I get the following warnings from the navigation task:
    - "could not get robot pose, cancelling reconfiguration"
    - "Costmap2DROS transform timeout. Current time: 153253596.3332, global_pose_stamp: 1532353713.8062, tolerance: 0.5000"
  
8. Please, describe detailedly what difficulty you are in 

    - Then in RViz I click to set the 2D Pose Estimate, I iterate to align laserscan dots with the occupancy map. The problem is that when I set a nav goal or move the robot by teleoperation, the robot does not move on the map.
And I get warning over and over in the console.

I'm pretty new to ROS but as the robot does not move on the map, I feel like the amcl is not working for some reason.
How to troubleshoot and fix ? I'm starting to feel like a turtle without salad !

DoNcK

---

Some screenshots and extra info:

Strange stuffs I noticed:

rostopic hz /amcl_pose
=> no new messages

and on roswtf:

Found 1 error(s).

/cmd_vel topic doesn't move the dynamixels
body:
ISSUE TEMPLATE ver. 0.1.0

1. Which TurtleBot3 you have?

Burger

2. Which SBC(Single Board Computer) is working on TurtleBot3?

Raspberry Pi 3

3. Which OS you installed in SBC?

Ubuntu MATE 16.04

4. Which OS you installed in Remote PC?

Ubuntu 16.04 LTS (Xenial Xerus)

5. Write down the commands you used in order

    [Remote PC] roscore
    [SBC] roslaunch turtlebot3_bringup turtlebot3_robot.launch
    [Remote PC] roslaunch turtlebot3_teleop turtlebot3_teleop_key.launch
 
6. Copy and Paste your error message on terminal

   None
  
7. Please, describe detailedly what difficulty you are in 

    -Hi,

I have a problem with turtlebot3 movement and I was hoping I can get some help from you.
I am building a turtlebot3 but instead of making it with the black original frames that are portrayed in the website, I'm using my own patterned plates and brackets as the structure, so the only thing different about it is the structure. All the other components like dynamixels and boards and Lidar sensor are the same as in the ROBOTIS website.
I managed to bring the robot up until the end of the "Bring-Up" part on the e-manual, but when I want to move the robot using the "teleop" I don't get anything.
I have my turtlebot3 and remote PC connected through wifi, I can see that the "/cmd_vel" topic is being published in when I get the echo of the topic in the turtlebot PC, I see two of the red lights on the OpenCR board, which are indicating the number of users, get lit, but I have no movement in the robot because the dynamixels are staying stationary. I even tried publishing into the /cmd_vel topic manually in the turtlebot PC but that didn't work either.

Let me emphasize that the only difference between the original turtlebot3-burger and my turtlebot3 is the model of the structure and the related matters like URDF models and etc.
 
I will really appreciate the smallest help.
Thank you.

title: OpenCR board no longer showing up on Serial after uploading Manipulator image
body:
ISSUE TEMPLATE ver. 0.1.0

1. Which TurtleBot3 you have?

    - [ ] Burger
    - [ ] Waffle
    - [X] Waffle Pi

2. Which SBC(Single Board Computer) is working on TurtleBot3?

    - [X] Raspberry Pi 3
    - [ ] Intel Joule 570x
    - [ ] etc (PLEASE, WRITE DOWN YOUR SBC HERE)

3. Which OS you installed in SBC?

    - [X] Ubuntu MATE 16.04 or later
    - [ ] Raspbian
    - [ ] etc (PLEASE, WRITE DOWN YOUR OS)

4. Which OS you installed in Remote PC?

    - [X] Ubuntu 16.04 LTS (Xenial Xerus)
    - [ ] Ubuntu 18.04 LTS (Bionic Beaver)
    - [ ] Linux Mint 18.x
    - [ ] etc (PLEASE, WRITE DOWN YOUR OS)

3. Write down software version and firmware version

    - Software version: [ROS Kinetic 1.12.13]
    - Firmware version: [1.2.0]
 

6. Please, describe detailedly what difficulty you are in 
Hi, I am having a similar issue to #240. I commented out the same line of code because it wasn't compiling: `DEBUG_SERIAL.print("Bumper : "); DEBUG_SERIAL.println(sensors.getPushedBumper());
`
I also changed the joints to 5 and the grip joints to 1, and renamed the joints in the image since I have a custom arm (used Robotis supported Dynamixel motors). After uploading the arduino image, the OpenCR board no longer shows up on Linux and Windows outputs a USB device not recognized error message.

I changed the code to the recommended `checkPushBumper `function but the board does not show up anymore. It showed up fine before I uploaded the image.

title: Corret the laser scanner update_rate in the gazebo xacro files
body: According to the issue #253, change the update_rate from 1800 to 5.

title: Why turtlebot3_navigation package could run without source file of move_base and amcl?
body:
In turtlebot3_navigation package, I found the launch files of amcl and move_base.
These launch files can be executed according to emanual->navigation.
However, I could not find any source files about acml and move_base in turtlebot3 package.
I'm just curious about it.
Could you introduce some links or material introducing how you realized it?
Thank you very much!

title: Update my Burger to Waffle, 	I need to by Intel® Joule™ 570x or I have other options?
body:
Hi team,
I am planning to update my Burger to a Waffle. Coz I think it will be more powerful to support a 3D camera(I might be wrong). So I want to buy an Intel® Joule™ 570x, but Intel discontinued the products. My question is do I sill try to buy a Joule or I have other options as the onboard PC? What is your plan?
Secondly, I also wanna buy an Openmanipulator. Will you sell it as a whole thing SOON or I still need to 3D print the link parts. Thanks a lot.

Steven

title: Scan message publish rate of the Turtlebot3 LIDAR
body:
Hi, 
I have a Turtlebot3 waffle, which equipped with a LDS-01 LIDAR. I use the standard launch file to start the LIDAR. 
`roslaunch turtlebot3_bringup turtlebot3_lidar.launch`

However, my measuring of the /scan message publish rate is about 5Hz, and my application needs higher rate. I wonder if there is any way to increase the /scan message publish rate?

Hi,

I'm relatively new to ROS and the turtlebot.

When I try to bringup the turtlebot, there is no error message, but the tf tree seems to be incomplete.

The only transformations broadcasted are odom -> base_footprint and base_link -> imu_link.

So when I start rviz for example it misses some parts of tf (eg for the laser scanner).

How can I bring up the remaining transformations? Where are they called from? As far as I can tell, in the Arduino file, only the above mentioned transformations are broadcasted.

Thanks in advance!

title: Questions about base mesh files
body:
Hello all,

I am doing some modifications on the Turtlebot3 Waffle frames to have space for some more sensors, as you can see below. I am working at a forked workspace on Onshape, and exporting it to use as a base mesh in the urdf.

![waffle_third](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20625381/41888480-a40227f2-7940-11e8-87f3-44b811e9e3a0.png)

So here are my questions:
-  Why are the meshes in this directory (e.g. `waffle_base.stl`) different from the ones exportable by the Onshape workspace (plates have less holes on it, etc)? Is it to make the files smaller? If so can we have access to editables for such plates?
- Is there any reasons for the files being .stl rather than .dae? When exporting from Onshape collada files appear to be smaller on size, preserve color and do not need the `scale` or `material` tags in the urdf.

title: Can not upload to OpenCR
body:
Hello,

First of all thank you for the work you have done and you are doing, Turtlebot3 is a great project.

I am working on the Turtlebot3 waffle and I use Jetson TX2 as a SBC. 
We have recently purchased Open Manipulator arm for Turtlebot3.
I followed all the steps from the Emanual wiki to setup the hardware.

I have managed to set up Turtlebot3 and the robot was moving just fine, when I uploaded the turtlebot_core to the board, with OpenCR version 1.1.2.


The problem occured when I updated the version of OpenCR to 1.2.0 using Arduiono IDE to upload from examples turtlebot_with_open_manipulator_core to the board and test the dynamixel arm.
IDE is able to detect the board - dev/ttyACM0 and also I detect the board with libusb command.
When I upload the file I get following error:

Arduino: 1.8.5 (Linux), Board: "OpenCR Board, OpenCR Bootloader"

/home/das-note-2/.arduino15/packages/OpenCR/hardware/OpenCR/1.2.0/libraries/turtlebot3/examples/turtlebot3_with_open_manipulator/turtlebot3_with_open_manipulator_core/turtlebot3_with_open_manipulator_core.ino: In function 'void sendDebuglog()':
turtlebot3_with_open_manipulator_core:764: error: 'class Turtlebot3Sensor' has no member named 'getPushedBumper'
   DEBUG_SERIAL.print("Bumper : "); DEBUG_SERIAL.println(sensors.getPushedBumper());
                                                                 ^
exit status 1
'class Turtlebot3Sensor' has no member named 'getPushedBumper'

This report would have more information with
"Show verbose output during compilation"
option enabled in File -> Preferences.


Next I commented out the following line:
           DEBUG_SERIAL.print("Bumper : "); DEBUG_SERIAL.println(sensors.getPushedBumper());
and tried to upload again, and managed to upload to the board.

However, the sample program to bringup the turtlebot3 with the open manipulator did not run, and I decided to rewrite the turtlebot3_core to the board to reset to working settings.

Now I am facing the following error, regardless of OpenCR version and what kind of sample I try to upload to the board, the IDE and the shell show:
            cmd_read_board_name fail : 0xF020

I have to note, that there is no a time value next 0xF020 comparing to https://github.com/ROBOTIS-GIT/OpenCR/issues/65

I have checked every connections several times. I can see on the board only the USB and POWER leds are on. 
I also tried to to burn the Bootloader and dowload the bootloader, also checked the USB port settings. and followed the wiki provided.
I have tried following OpenCR versions - 1.1.12, 1.1.13, 1.1.15, 1.1.0, 1.2.0 
I would like to know whether I am having problems with the hardware or is there smth wrong with my software settings?

Do you have any idea to solve this problem?
Any kind of help or advice will be appreciated!
Thanks in advance,
Husni.

title: Fix turtlebot3 dependencies
body:
Trying to `catkin build turtlebot3` gives the following error
```
error: ‘const struct turtlebot3_msgs::SensorState_<std::allocator<void>’ has no member named ‘torque’ 
if (msg->torque == true)
```
Which is caused by lack of dependency on `turtlebot3_msgs`.

Although it builds fine with `catkin_make`, it should be better to have clear dependencies for each package.

title: Scan lines hitting the front camera on `waffle` turtlebot3 gazebo simulation
body:
There is an issue with the Gazebo simulation of `TURTLEBOT3_MODEL=waffle`, the one with both a single-channel lidar and a realsense camera. This only happens on `waffle` and not `waffle_pi` or `burger`.

Some of the lidar's scan lines are blocked the realsense camera attached to the front of the robot. This causes the navigation stack to sometimes act as if there is an obstacle directly in front of the robot. Navigation mostly still works, but this causes the `waffle` robot to occasionally back up for no apparent reason.

Here are a few images from rviz showing what's going on with the scan lines. Notice the red dots toward the front of the robot. This does not occur with `waffle_pi` or `burger`.

![rviz_lidar_blocked2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/867278/41173367-9a868ad0-6b24-11e8-9eb0-b4d05332a851.png)
![rviz_lidar_blocked](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/867278/41173370-9bdec3e8-6b24-11e8-991e-5b913d2cef87.png)

Let me know if I can provide any additional data that's useful for this issue's resolution.

title: Referred by tech support, what is What is the minimum resolution of position X, Y that can be used in 2D point operation?
body:
I am working on a project where a TurtleBot3 Burger will be moved to X Y coordinates, where those coordinates expressed in millimeters (mm).
 
The documentation for Point Operation  in the Example section of the e-manual may be what I need:
http://emanual.robotis.com/docs/en/platform/turtlebot3/example/#point-operation
 
(Note: I am ignoring Z coordinate in the remainder of this discussion, assume it will always have a value of 0)
 
When I look at the underlying source code, it appears the X Y coordinates are input in terms of meters:
https://github.com/ROBOTIS-GIT/turtlebot3/blob/master/turtlebot3_example/nodes/turtlebot3_pointop_key
 
My question is this:  what is the minimum resolution of X Y coordinates that can be used? For example, if I wanted to move to point (X=5mm, Y=5mm) from the origin, can that be input as (.005, .005) to the Point Operation  example?

title: Use relative names instead of global names
body:
One of ROS best-practice is to not use global names until one absolutely has to. This is because global names can not be pushed into a new namespace, which will become trouble if for example someone wants to support multiple robots etc.
This is documented in several places in ROS wiki:
- [Names that start with a "/" are global -- they are considered fully resolved. Global names should be avoided as much as possible as they limit code portability.](http://wiki.ros.org/Names)
- [If you really want you can specify a global name. This is generally discouraged, as it prevents nodes from being pushed into namespaces (e.g. by roslaunch).](http://wiki.ros.org/roscpp/Overview/NodeHandles)

This pull request converts all instances of global names to relative names where it's reasonable.

title: Multiple TurtleBot3's
body:
Hello,

I am attempting to work with two TurtleBot3 platforms simultaneously.  For the ROS topics/services, using a namespace works just fine with small edits to the bringup launch file.

The problem I have is how to add a prefix to the TF broadcasting done by the turtlebot3_core node.  It appears that the TF determination is done on the OpenCR board and then sent over serial using rosserial_python/serial_node.py.

I did try adding a "tf_prefix" parameter definition, but it appears that this is not implemented for the OpenCR/rosserial_python solution.

Any ideas on how to add distinct TF prefixes to each robot (e.g., "robot1/odom" and "robot2/odom", etc. for two robots)?

The only thing I can think of is to add a #define to the [turtlebot3_core_config.h](https://github.com/ROBOTIS-GIT/OpenCR/blob/master/arduino/opencr_arduino/opencr/libraries/turtlebot3/examples/turtlebot3_burger/turtlebot3_core/turtlebot3_core_config.h), but that would require recompiling the firmware for each change, which doesn't seem like a good solution.

Thank you,
Brian

- [ ] Raspberry Pi 3
- [ ] Intel Joule
- [ x] etc (PLEASE, WRITE DOWN YOUR SBC HERE)

3. Which OS you installed in SBC?

- [ ] Ubuntu MATE 16.04 or later
- [ ] Raspbian
- [ ] etc (PLEASE, WRITE DOWN YOUR OS)

4. Which OS you installed in RemotePC?

- [ x] Ubuntu 16.04 LTS (Xenial Xerus)
- [ ] Ubuntu 18.04 LTS (Bionic Beaver)
- [ ] Linux Mint 18.X
- [ ] etc (PLEASE, WRITE DOWN YOUR OS)


I am planning to use an Upboard Squard in Combination with TurtleBot 3 waffle PI.
So my question is if i can simply use the installation Guide provided for the intel joule to bring it up and working.
The main issue with the raspberry PI is its limitation on usb 2.0.

title: update
body:
1. update urdf and gazebo configuration for turtlebot3 with openmanipulator
1. update navigation param

title: Can't use rviz turtlebot3 slam configuration file
body:

(Here it fails)

I also try to use the fourth command without launching any ros slam node. It gives me the same message. If I don't use Rviz, I manage to save a map with the map_server. I can open it with gimp and it's ok. But I would like to visualize it with Rviz. 

Other information. Rviz works fine with the configuration file in turtlebot_description and I can notice the laser data in the Rviz environment. 

I first thought I had to synchronize with ntpdate. But I've just done it and it gives me the same. 

Anyone would have any idea to help ? 

Thank you in advance :)

ps : I use a turtlebot3 burger with the recommended configurations.

My question is that, I didn't find these pkg code( cpp and python) in Turtlebot3, are they given by ROS directly? Because when I learnt navigation part, the navigation launch file are totally the same.

Thank you!

title: Waffle Pi cannot map properly
body:
Good afternoon,

After a few attempts, it was not possible to do the first mapping with Turtle Bot 3 Waffle Pi. It seems that the Robot loses its reference, and starts to map over the existing map, as you can see in the pictures below.

![screenshot from 2018-04-26 13-36-17](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/36993172/39444081-de064324-4c8c-11e8-9e69-22a10679bf38.png)
![scrsht](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/36993172/39444083-de5a8fa6-4c8c-11e8-90fb-02f2b8100f23.png)

Have you experienced something similar? I'd appreciate some help. Thank you!

title: TurtleBot not mapping properly
body:
Hi, I have always been able to map with my turtlebot using the [tutorial](http://emanual.robotis.com/docs/en/platform/turtlebot3/slam/#slam) until recently. Now I can no longer generate maps as my turtlebot seem to stay in one location on the map in Rviz even though it is moving around in reality. As a result it always overlay all generated map from the laserscans at the same spot.

![rviz_error1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/29714471/39389510-3928f702-4a57-11e8-86bc-6b024dbf23b9.png)

The same thing is applicable if I just use the [tutorial](http://emanual.robotis.com/docs/en/platform/turtlebot3/bringup/#bringup) for bringup and teleoperation. In the rviz, the robot wheels spin but the turtlebot stays in the same spot and never moves.

![rviz_error2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/29714471/39389596-0b514f4a-4a58-11e8-8ede-d5560bbe15f3.png)

I have tried reinstalling all the packages and reinitializing the OpenCR and motors to no avail. Any advice or help will be highly appreciated. Thanks!

title: Odom doesn't move.
body: The robot's odom wont move. When using the teleop, everything moves except the odom.

title: Opencr board not connecting through usb and overheating
body: My name is Hunter and I am working on a group project and my teammate Michael has called recently. We are working on an opencr board with a pololu shield. Today when I sat down to work on the opencr board, it would not connect to a desktop or the pi that normally runs it. It also gets very hot quickly when plugged into power or the computer via usb. I have run into the board not connecting to the computer before but have always fixed it by holding the sw2 button and then pressing the reset button. Now that does not work. Trying to get it into DFU mode has also been unsuccessful. Any advice on how to salvage the board so I upload code to it again would be helpful.

title: /dev/tty/ACM0 disappears when OpenCR's 12V output is used
body:
I'm trying to connect a custom circuit board to the OpenCR card, using the 12V output show at the left of the following image as a source (this custom board doesn't take up more than some miliamps of current).

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15084103/38998996-17ef3478-43f1-11e8-9cc0-0a6404b0425c.png)

Nevertheless, at the moment that I connect to this output, the USB connection from the OpenCR board to the Raspberry Pi is lost. Using `$ watch ls /dev/ -m` I was able to see that it indeed happens at the very moment I plug it in.

Plugging and unplugging the USB cable does nothing, the device can only be seen after turning the OpenCR board off and on again.

What could be the issue? Thanks in advance for any tips that might help me to identify the problem.

**UPDATE:**
When I connect to the _Power Out_ output  (J10 on the OpenCR schematics) instead of the 12V regulated output, I don't have the problem anymore. I would still like to know what is the problem though with the 12V output though, as I suspect one of the two might be happening:

1.  Maybe the OpenCR card can't power its USB port correctly when I'm taking some current from the 12V output;
2.  Maybe, when taking this amount of current from the 12V output, the 5V output (which is being used to power the Raspberry Pi) is perturbed in a way that makes the Raspberry Pi's USB port unstable.

**UPDATE2:**

The problem came back after trying to use my card, even using the Power Out output. I tried powering the card with an external source and I still had the same problem, which means that it's not a matter of current drain. 
**This card sends 3 analog input signals to the OpenCR analog inputs, is it possible that receiving these analog signals perturbs the USB connection?**

title: USB Connection for Firmware change
body: If I would try to play with the firmware - modify and upload via Arduino IDE in the host computer.. shall I connect the usb cable to the OpenCR directly, not to the Joule board? That's what I would assume but hope to confirm.

title: Turtlebot3 realsense r200 loses connection after bringup
body:
Hi everyone,
I am new to the Turtlebot3 and I am finding troubles with the Intel Realsense r200 camera.
When I launch on the robot roslaunch turtlebot3_bringup turtlebot3_realsense.launch or roslaunch realsense_camera r200_nodelet_default.launch the nodes run but unfortunately it just connects to the serial port without going on and then it loses the connection from the Wifi.
This is what is displayed.

title: OpenCR does not boot
body:
Hello,

First of all thank you for the work you have done and you are doing, Turtlebot3 is a great project.

I am working on the Turtlebot3 waffle pi. I followed all the steps from the emanual to setup the hardware but at this [step](http://emanual.robotis.com/docs/en/platform/turtlebot3/hardware_setup/#basic-operation) the robot is not moving when the SW1 and SW2 push buttons are pressed.

I have checked every connections several times.
I can see on the board only the USB and POWER leds are on).

However, everything else seems to work properly (lidar, BT-410, raspberry pi (ssh connection working)).
I tried to detect the connection between the raspberry pi and the OpenCR over USB:
- with the IDE arduino but there was no ACM0 port displayed
- with lsusb command but nothing appeared related to the board 

I also tried with a personal USB cable between the OpenCR and my laptop, but the result was the same.

In addition, I tried to use the [recovery mode](http://emanual.robotis.com/docs/en/parts/controller/opencr10/#firmware-recovery-mode) but there was no activity from the board (the STATUS led remains off).

Do you have any idea to solve this problem?

Thanks in advance,
Yoann

title: TurtleBot Bringup Not Connecting to Port
body:
I've been using the TurtleBot3 Waffle with Intel Joule processor for about a month now, and everything has been working very smoothly up until yesterday. Yesterday I followed the same process I usually use to set the TurtleBot up to communicate with a Remote PC: [Remote PC] 1. Run `roscore` 2. Run `roslaunch turtlebot3_bringup turtlebot3_remote.launch` [TurtleBot] 1. Power up the robot 2. Run `roslaunch turtlebot3_bringup turtlebot3_robot.launch` After I run these steps, I usually am able to publish/subscribe to the various ROS topics the robot publishes/subscribes to. Yesterday I ran this setup and received this console output after launching the turtlebot3_robot.launch on the TurtleBot: Checking log directory for disk usage. This may take awhile. Press Ctrl-C to interrupt Done checking log file disk usage. Usage is <1GB. started roslaunch server http://[hostname]:45747/ SUMMARY ======== PARAMETERS * /rosdistro: kinetic * /rosversion: 1.12.13 * /turtlebot3_core/baud: 115200 * /turtlebot3_core/port: /dev/ttyACM0 * /turtlebot3_lds/frame_id: base_scan * /turtlebot3_lds/port: /dev/ttyUSB0 NODES / turtlebot3_core (rosserial_python/serial_node.py) turtlebot3_diagnostics (turtlebot3_bringup/turtlebot3_diagnostics) turtlebot3_lds (hls_lfcd_lds_driver/hlds_laser_publisher) ROS_MASTER_URI=http://[master_uri]:11311 process[turtlebot3_core-1]: started with pid [2603] process[turtlebot3_lds-2]: started with pid [2604] process[turtlebot3_diagnostics-3]: started with pid [2605] [INFO] [1522418950.044044, 0.000000]: ROS Serial Python Node [INFO] [1522418950.263477, 0.000000]: Connecting to /dev/ttyACM0 at 115200 baud
And that's as far as it gets. It's getting hung up on connecting the OpenCR port. The only similar scenario to mine that I've seen asked about on here is at the following link: (https://github.com/ROBOTIS-GIT/turtlebot3/issues/69). I've followed all the instructions in the answers provided with no successful. Strangely enough, I let the robot charge overnight, and when I powered it on again this morning, it worked fine for the first 3 or 4 times I ran the boot sequence above. Then I tried to start again after 3-4 successes, and I ran into the same issue. It gets stuck on the connecting step. I am able to connect to the OpenCR board and flash the turtlebot3_core firmware from the Arduino program, so I know I have connectivity to the board. It's just the turtlebot3_robot.launch sequence that seems to be having trouble with connecting. I'm planning to re-flash the BIOS for the Intel Joule processor being used alongside the OpenCR board. I have tried powering on and off, unplugging and plugging back in every port possible to try and diagnose the issue, but I haven't had any success. If more information is needed, I would be happy to provide it. Thanks for the help.

title: Launch may fail if I add any other USB Serial device to Turtlebot
body:
As I mentioned up on the Robotis forum: http://en.robotis.com/service/forum_view.php?bbs_no=2406735&slg=&page_type=&mode=&submode=

I am looking into maybe adding one or more sensors to detect a drop (cliff) like the Turtblebot 2 has, such that my new Waffle Pi does not fall down stairs if I have it mapping some rooms. 

Can probably add sensor and code to openCR board, but might at least start out by using an Arduino or Teensy (PJRC) to connect the sensor(s) to.  

Now suppose I plug in a Teensy into the RPI and it gets assigned to: /dev/ttyACM0 
or some other Arduinos may be assigned to /dev/ttyUSB0  than the current launch files won't work as they assume that the OpenCR board has the address /dev/ttyACM0 and the LDR has /dev/ttyUSB0

Hopefully soon I will try adding a sensor, and to work around this I plan to use UDEV rules to give the different devices standard unique names, such that you are not at the mercy of the USB system deciding on what order it will enumerate (and assign) the device names. 

Example I already tried updating your udev rule file like: 

    #cp rules /etc/udev/rules.d/
    #sudo udevadm control --reload-rules
    #sudo udevadm trigger

    ATTRS{idVendor}=="0483" ATTRS{idProduct}=="5740", ENV{ID_MM_DEVICE_IGNORE}="1", MODE:="0666"
    ATTRS{idVendor}=="0483" ATTRS{idProduct}=="df11", MODE:="0666"
    ATTRS{idVendor}=="fff1" ATTRS{idProduct}=="ff48", ENV{ID_MM_DEVICE_IGNORE}="1", MODE:="0666"
    ATTRS{idVendor}=="10c4" ATTRS{idProduct}=="ea60", ENV{ID_MM_DEVICE_IGNORE}="1", MODE:="0666"
    SUBSYSTEM=="tty", ATTRS{idVendor}=="0483", ATTRS{idProduct}=="5740", SYMLINK+="ttyOPENCR"

I run this on my RPI and if I now look at the device list, you will see that the alias was created:

    kurt@raspi-turtle:/etc/udev/rules.d$ ls /dev/tty*
    /dev/tty    /dev/tty13  /dev/tty19  /dev/tty24  /dev/tty3   /dev/tty35  /dev/tty40  /dev/tty46  /dev/tty51  /dev/tty57  /dev/tty62    /dev/ttyAMA0
    /dev/tty0   /dev/tty14  /dev/tty2   /dev/tty25  /dev/tty30  /dev/tty36  /dev/tty41  /dev/tty47  /dev/tty52  /dev/tty58  /dev/tty63    /dev/ttyOPENCR
    /dev/tty1   /dev/tty15  /dev/tty20  /dev/tty26  /dev/tty31  /dev/tty37  /dev/tty42  /dev/tty48  /dev/tty53  /dev/tty59  /dev/tty7     /dev/ttyprintk
    /dev/tty10  /dev/tty16  /dev/tty21  /dev/tty27  /dev/tty32  /dev/tty38  /dev/tty43  /dev/tty49  /dev/tty54  /dev/tty6   /dev/tty8     /dev/ttyUSB0
    /dev/tty11  /dev/tty17  /dev/tty22  /dev/tty28  /dev/tty33  /dev/tty39  /dev/tty44  /dev/tty5   /dev/tty55   /dev/tty60  /dev/tty9
    /dev/tty12  /dev/tty18  /dev/tty23  /dev/tty29  /dev/tty34  /dev/tty4   /dev/tty45  /dev/tty50  /dev/tty56  /dev/tty61  /dev/ttyACM0
    kurt@raspi-turtle:/etc/udev/rules.d$ ls -l /dev/ttyOPENCR
    lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root 7 Mar 25 18:03 /dev/ttyOPENCR -> ttyACM0

Next up, is to edit the launch files to use the /dev/ttyOPENCR name instead of /dev/ttyACM0

And likewise make the same changes for the LDR to probably create the name /dev/dev/ttyLDR and change it's launch file(s) as well

title: Make Turtlebot Bringup Works with Kinect v2
body:
Hi,

I would like to make a Turtlebot simulation works with Kinect V2. I was following this tutorial (http://wiki.ros.org/rtabmap_ros/Tutorials/MappingAndNavigationOnTurtlebothttp://wiki.ros.org/rtabmap_ros/Tutorials/MappingAndNavigationOnTurtlebot). 

I did the following attempt:

Kinect2 works with the driver freenect2 and can be communicated with ROS using the package iai_kinect2/kinect2_bridge.

I modified the turtlebot_bringup/launch/includes/3dsensor/kinect.launch.xml by chaning the driver include file to launch file for kinect2_bridge, and delete the arguments that are not used by kinect2_bridge. Here is the modified 3dsensor/kinect.launch.xml:

```xml
<launch>
  <!-- "camera" should uniquely identify the device. All topics are pushed down
       into the "camera" namespace, and it is prepended to tf frame ids. -->
  <arg name="publish_tf"  default="false"/>

  <!-- Processing Modules -->                                    
                                                                                                                                                      
  <!-- <include file="$(find freenect_launch)/launch/freenect.launch">  --> 
<include file="/home/user_name/catkin_ws/src/iai_kinect2/kinect2_bridge/launch/kinect2_bridge.launch">                           
    <arg name="publish_tf"                      value="$(arg publish_tf)"/>                                          
                                                                                                                
    <!-- Processing Modules -->                                                                         
  </include>                                                                                        
</launch>
```
However, when I call up the turtlebot_bringup, I get this error:
```
unused args [num_worker_threads, rgb_processing, depth_registration, camera, depth_processing, 
ir_processing, disparity_processing, disparity_registered_processing, depth_registered_processing]
 for include of [/opt/ros/kinetic/share/turtlebot_bringup/launch/includes/3dsensor/kinect.launch.xml]
```

I don't understand this error, since I already deleted those arguments that are not used by the kinect2_bridge.launch, but I still get the above error.

Does anyone knows how to solve this problem?

Please let me know if I did not provide enough infomation!
